[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result(), err_result()] [Module boundary exploitation] Can these helper functions be called directly by user Move code, or are they only accessible to native functions? If accessible, can user code create invalid Result values? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Reference determinism] Does is_ok_result_ref() produce deterministic boolean results across all validators, or can race conditions in reference handling cause different nodes to see different Ok/Err states? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result()] [State serialization] When Result values created by ok_result() are serialized to storage, can the serialization format introduce ambiguities that allow Result::Ok to be deserialized as Result::Err? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Transaction validation bypass] Can a malicious transaction use unwrap_result() on a crafted Result value to bypass transaction validation in aptos_framework::transaction_validation.move? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Staking state confusion] In staking.move, if is_ok_result_ref() returns incorrect boolean values due to VM bugs, can attackers manipulate validator registration or reward distribution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Coin transfer exploit] Can unwrap_result() be exploited in coin.move to extract coin values from Result::Err states, effectively creating coins from error conditions? (Critical)
